snippet: The last abortion clinics in two poor and working-class regions were closing, and the number of Texas clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.
abstract: Closings of last abortion clinics in McAllen and Beaumont, two poor and working-class regions of Texas, are part of wave of clinic closings brought on by tough new state law; number of abortion clinics now numbers 24, from 44 in 2011, and is expected to drop to six, as abortion costs rise.

byline.contributor: Lucinda Holt contributed reporting from Lubbock, Tex.

lead_paragraph: The last abortion clinics in two poor and working-class regions were closing, and the number of Texas clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.

headline.main: Abortion Law Pushes Texas Clinics to Close Doors
headline.print_headline: Abortion Law Pushes Clinics to Close Doors
